dt: {bc}a small knife used especially for {a_link|spreading} butter
{bc}a device (such as a bar) holding two linear elements (such as lines, guys, rails) apart and usually taut

shortdef: a small knife used especially for spreading butter

dt: {bc}an individual who is highly contagious and capable of transmitting a {d_link|communicable|communicable} disease to an unusually large number of uninfected individuals

dt.t: Health authorities are watching uneasily for an event that could reverse their apparent success in containing the U.S. outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome: the arrival of a so-called {wi}super-spreader{/wi}.

The story of a traveling British businessman who appears to have passed the coronavirus to Britons in at least three countries has prompted concerns over a {lsquo}{wi}superspreader{/wi},{rsquo} who could play an outsize role in transmitting the infection.

dt: {bc}an event or location at which a significant number of people contract the same communicable disease

dt.t: So far, {wi}super-spreader{/wi} events have occurred in a range of places including meat packing plants, prisons, nightclubs and bars—basically any venue where people are in close proximity of one another, ventilation is poor and the virus gets the opportunity to spread like wildfire.

The influx of students had quickly turned Minot State University into a {wi}superspreader{/wi} site: within two weeks, more than ten per cent of the coronavirus tests that students received were coming back positive.

shortdef: an individual who is highly contagious and capable of transmitting a communicable disease to an unusually large number of uninfected individuals
an event or location at which a significant number of people contract the same communicable disease —often used before another noun

dt.t: He was {wi}silent{/wi} for a full minute, as he often is when answering a hard question.
They all {phrase}fell silent{/phrase}, looking rather scared.
As a former {wi}silent{/wi} person, part of me gravitates to talkers.

When ABC's promos boast the crime unit portrayed here is not {ldquo}your father's FBI,{rdquo} it's insinuating that dad's FBI agents were balding, nerdy guys or the stereotypical {phrase}strong, silent types{/phrase}.
The house was eerily {wi}silent{/wi}.
{wi}silent{/wi} prayer
{wi}silent{/wi} grief
history is {wi}silent{/wi} about this person

dt: {bc}not widely or generally known or appreciated

dt.t: the {wi}silent{/wi} pressures on a person in public office
the {wi}silent{/wi} majority
the {wi}silent{/wi} {it}b{/it} in {it}doubt{/it}

dt: {bc}not exhibiting or producing the usual signs or symptoms of presence

dt.t: {wi}silent{/wi} urinary tract infections
A "{wi}silent{/wi} stroke" has none of the warning signs of a larger stroke: severe headaches, dizziness, loss of motor skills. Often victims do not realize they have had strokes.

dt: {bc}relating to or being an infectious disease or pathogen that spreads undetected within a population

dt.t: Chlamydia can cause fertility problems for women, but is generally asymptomatic, meaning the infection presents no immediate symptoms, said Dr. James Gaskell, health commissioner for the Athens City-County Health Department. As a result, it spreads quickly in dense populations like college campuses, he said. "It's a {phrase}silent spreader{/phrase}, if you will," Gaskell said.

dt: {bc}being, involving, or caused by an {d_link|asymptomatic|asymptomatic} or {d_link|presymptomatic|presymptomatic} infectious individual

dt.t: {wi}silent{/wi} spread/transmission of contagious disease

Since a novel coronavirus first made its presence known in China, public health officials around the world have had one fervent hope: That people who are infected but not sick would pass the virus to others only rarely. That would give these {phrase}silent spreaders{/phrase} no more than a bit part in driving a global outbreak. That hope is in danger of being dashed.
{wi}silent{/wi} movies

pt: {sc}silent{/sc} {sc}taciturn{/sc} {sc}reticent{/sc} {sc}reserved{/sc} {sc}secretive{/sc} mean showing restraint in speaking. {sc}silent{/sc} implies a habit of saying no more than is needed.
{sc}taciturn{/sc} implies a temperamental disinclination to speech and usually connotes unsociability.
{sc}reticent{/sc} implies a reluctance to speak out or at length, especially about one's own affairs.
{sc}reserved{/sc} implies reticence and suggests the restraining influence of caution or formality in checking easy informal conversational exchange.
{sc}secretive{/sc}, too, implies reticence but usually carries a suggestion of deviousness and lack of frankness or of an often ostentatious will to conceal.

et: Middle English {it}sylent{/it}, from Latin {it}silent-, silens{/it}, from present participle of {it}silēre{/it} to be silent; akin to Goth ana{it}silan{/it} to cease, grow calm
shortdef: making no utterance : not speaking or making noise
tending to speak very little : not loquacious
free from sound or noise : still
